title: Bullpen gives Royals huge advantage over Astros
text:
Bullpen gives Royals huge advantage over Astros Resize Text By Neil Greenberg October 8 at 1:24 PM Follow @ngreenberg (Getty Images) 
A baseball game is typically nine innings long, but all the Royals need is six solid innings from their starter before handing it over to the bullpen, which is one of the best in the majors. 
The Kansas City bullpen ranks second in ERA (2.72) and has a healthy lead in FanGraphs’ runs against based wins above replacement, or RA9-WAR . 
“ We have guys down there, when we have the lead and the ball is in their hands, we feel comfortable ,” first baseman Eric Hosmer said of the bullpen. “That’s what we rode in the playoffs last year and what we hope we can ride this year.” 
Kansas City’s bullpen was a major factor in the team getting to a deciding Game 7 in last year’s World Series, and they were worth a collective 7.4 wins above replacement by RA9-WAR — more than two wins worse than this year’s group. 
And despite losing closer Greg Holland for the playoffs because of a UCL tear he revealed in September, this team has four workhorses it can turn to late in the game for a win, starting with Danny Duffy. 
Manger Ned Yost sent the struggling left-hander to the bullpen, but he has performed when asked to in a relief role. He has struck out 12 batters in 8 1/3 innings pitched and has increased the frequency of his fastball, which is now being thrown more than 71 percent of the time. 
And that’s help keep batters on both sides of the plate from hitting for too much power. 
Kelvin Herrera struggled in August and September but averaged more than 97 mph on his fastball and has held opposing batters to a .531 OPS against in high-leverage situations, those times when the game is most on the line. 
Ryan Madson has lost the past four seasons to injury but bounced back to post a 2.13 ERA while striking out 58 batters in 63 1/3 innings of work, walking just 14. He has the second highest context neutral wins , or WPA/LI , on the team (1.00), which directly measure a player’s contributions to his team’s win expectancy, while neutralizing for leverage index so that players don’t get a large bonus by being in high leverage situations more often. Only current closer Wade Davis has been better (2.18 WPA/LI), and he has the highest mark among all of baseball’s qualified relievers. 
Davis’s fastball has held opposing hitters to a .155 average against with 40 strikeouts over 116 at-bats ending with the pitch this season, but his curve and cutter have also been as unhittable: .163 against the former and .129 against the latter. 
“ He’s been one of the most dominant relievers in all of baseball , and Wade doesn’t care what inning it’s in, if it’s the eighth or the ninth,” Yost said. “I mean, he had 11, 12, 13 saves before we named him the closer, so I mean, he was well familiar with that type of inning. He just goes out and gets it done.” Neil Greenberg analyzes advanced sports statistics for the Fancy Stats blog and prefers to be called a geek rather than a nerd. sports Success!
